content:
• Wednesday, May 25, 2016
  • HEI

    HEICO reports FQ2 results

    • HEICO (NYSE:HEI): FQ2 EPS of $0.57
    • Revenue of $350.65M (+20.3% Y/Y)
    • Shares +1.7% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:34 PM
  • RUBI

    Rubicon Project CFO Tappin resigns to take new job

    • Rubicon Project (RUBI +1.6%) says Chief Financial Officer Todd Tappin has resigned, in order to become president of another company.
    • Shares have fallen 4% after hours.
    • Rubicon Project's chief accounting officer, David Day, is taking over on an interim basis while the company looks for a permanent CFO.
    • Tappin will remain a strategic adviser to Rubicon Project. Day, who joined the company in 2013, was previously chief accounting officer at ReachLocal as well as serving as senior VP of Finance at Overture.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:45 PM

  • After Hours Gainers / Losers

    • Top gainers, as of 5.25 p.m.: LGF +13.3%. PVH +6.7%. CEMP +4.5%. WSM +3.6%. NYRT +2.7%.
    • Top losers, as of 5.25p.m.: PSTG -15.2%. NTAP -7.7%. PLKI -6.8%. WBMD -4.8%. RUBI -3.9%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:39 PM
  • PSTG

    Pure Storage tumbles after slight FQ1 beat, in-line FQ2 guidance; no FY17 sales outlook given

    • With investors accustomed to seeing the company deliver large beats against a backdrop of conservative post-IPO analyst estimates, Pure Storage (NYSE:PSTG) is down 15.1% after hours to $12.50 after slightly beating FQ1 estimates and guiding for FQ2 revenue of $153M-$157M vs. a $153.8M consensus. Notably, Pure didn't issue FY17 (ends Jan. '17) sales guidance in its earnings report, as it did in March.
    • Top-line performance: Product revenue (drives future support revenue) rose 75% Y/Y in FQ1 to $111.7M, a slowdown from FQ4's 120% growth. Support revenue rose 169% to $28.2M. Nearly 300 new customers were added (roughly on par with FQ4), raising the total base to more than 1,950. New clients included SoftBank and The World Bank.
    • Financials: Non-GAAP gross margin rose 680 bps Y/Y to 67.3%, putting it within a 65%-68% guidance range. FQ2 GM guidance is also at 65%-68%. GAAP operating expenses rose 69% Y/Y to $157M. Pure ended FQ1 with $607M in cash/investments and no debt.
    • Pure's FQ1 results, earnings release, CEO commentary
     
     
     
     
    | 5:33 PM | 2 Comments
  • MSLP

    MusclePharm axes endorsement deal with Tiger Woods

    • With the aim of cutting expenses, struggling sports nutrition firm MusclePharm (OTCQB:MSLP) terminates its endorsement deal with golfer Tiger Woods. The chronically cash-poor company is mired in lawsuits as it attempts to stabilize its business. Supplier Capstone Nutrition filed a $65M breach of contract suit a few days ago.
    • Shares were down over 10% today before recovering.
    • Update: The company agreed to pay $2.5M to terminate the contract with Mr. Woods and eliminate all future costs and obligations, a good deal considering it owed $7M.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:57 PM | 28 Comments
  • OVAS-OLD

    OvaScience initiates equity offering; shares down 23% premarket on Thursday

    • OvaScience (NASDAQ:OVAS-OLD) commences a public offering of common stock. Price, volume and terms have yet to be announced.
    • Update: The company prices its 7.15M-share offering at $7 a share. Underwriters over-allotment is an additional 1,072,500 shares. Closing date is June 1. Net proceeds of ~$46.8M will fund the commercial expansion of AUGMENT in Japan and Canada, pre-commercial activities supporting OvaPrime and OvaTure, working capital and general corporate purposes.
    • Shares are down 23% premarket on increased volume.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:48 PM | 6 Comments
  • PRGNF

    Paragon Shipping gets Nasdaq non-compliance, to drop to OTC Market

    • Paragon Shipping (PRGN) -27.6% AH after the company says it received a notice from Nasdaq of non-compliance since its shareholders equity was below the minimum $2.5M requirement.
    • PRGN says it will voluntarily move its common stock listing to the OTC Markets' OTCQB Venture Market, and expects trading will commence June 6 under the ticker symbol PRGNF.
    • The board says it determined that the company would be unlikely to regain compliance with the minimum stockholders' equity requirement within the timeframes required by Nasdaq.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:41 PM | 3 Comments
  • LGF.A

    Lions Gate +14.4% with fiscal Q4 beat, record backlog

    • Lions Gate Entertainment (LGF) has zoomed 14.4% after hours, following fiscal Q4 earnings where earnings fell alongside lighter box office but beat expectations easily with the help of TV.
    • Profit nearly halved from the year-ago quarter despite a 22% increase in revenues. EBITDA fell to $45.8M from a year-ago $90.4M, but beat an expected $29.3M. And film backlog -- already contracted revenue -- reached record levels.
    • Fiscal year revenue breakout: Motion Pictures, $1.68B (down 7.7%); Television, $669.9M (up 15.6%). In Motion Pictures, Theatrical revenue fell to $314.1M from $354M, and Home Entertainment revenues dropped to $640.1M from a year-ago $707.5M.
    • In Television, domestic revenues were comparable to before but international revenues ran to $190.2M from the previous $112.4M, thanks to the Pilgrim Studios acquisition and a global deal for Orange is the New Black.
    • "Although last year's film slate didn't match the performance of previous years, this year's slate is bigger, more balanced and is expected to generate greater profitability," says CEO Jon Feltheimer.
    • Filmed entertainment backlog hit a record $1.5B, up from last quarter's $1.3B.
    • Conference call to come tomorrow at 9 a.m. ET.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:35 PM | 2 Comments
  • WSM

    Williams-Sonoma higher after earnings and guidance satisfy

    • Williams-Sonoma (NYSE:WSM) reports comparable brand revenue growth of 4.5% in Q1. All the company's brands showed positive comp growth, led by West Elm (+19%) and Williams-Sonoma (+3.5%).
    • E-commerce revenue increased 8.2% to $576M.
    • Key metrics: Gross margin rate -100 bps Y/Y to 35.8%. Operating margin rate on a non-GAAP basis was 7.0%. Merchandise margin was lower during the quarter.
    • Williams Sonoma guides for Q2 revenue of $1.145B to $1.175B vs. $1.17B consensus and EPS of $0.54 to $0.60 vs. $0.60 consensus. The view for the full-year is revenue of $5.15B to $5.25B vs. $5.21B and EPS of $3.50 to $3.60 vs. $3.55 consensus.
    • Previously: Williams-Sonoma beats by $0.03, beats on revenue (May 25)
    • WSM +3.84% AH to $54.00.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:26 PM | 1 Comment
  • NTAP

    NetApp -2.9% on Q4 miss, light profit guidance

    • NetApp (NASDAQ:NTAP) has slipped 2.9% after hours, following a miss on profits and revenues and an outlook on next-quarter profits dimmer than analysts expected.
    • Product sales hurt revenues, which fell 10%. "We continue to advance our pivot to the growth segments of the market while, at the same time, streamlining the business and reducing our cost base," says CEO George Kurian.
    • Revenue breakout: Product, $757M (down 17.1%); Software maintenance, $234M (up 3.1%); Hardware maintenance and other services, $389M (down 2.5%).
    • It guided to fiscal Q1 revenues of $1.2B-$1.35B (in line) and non-GAAP EPS of $0.34-$0.39, below an expected $0.45.
    • in highlights, it noted deferred revenue and financed unearned services revenue for fiscal 2016 was up 6% Y/Y, and clustered Data ONTAP node shipments grew 85% from the prior year.
    • The company added Equinix CEO Steve Smith to its board, bringing total directors to 10 (nine independent). It also authorized an increase in the quarterly dividend to $0.19 for fiscal Q1.
    • Conference call to come at 5 p.m. ET.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:19 PM
  • PVH

    Phillips-Van Heusen beats by $0.07, beats on revenue

    • Phillips-Van Heusen (NYSE:PVH): Q1 EPS of $1.50 beats by $0.07.
    • Revenue of $1.92B (+2.1% Y/Y) beats by $20M.
    • Shares +8.4%.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:17 PM | 2 Comments

    SpartanNash beats by $0.05, revenue in-line

    • Revenue of $2.28B (-1.3% Y/Y) in-line.
    • Shares +2.5%.

  • LGF.A

    Lions Gate Entertainment beats by $0.09, beats on revenue

    • Lions Gate Entertainment (LGF): FQ4 EPS of $0.07 beats by $0.09.
    • Revenue of $791.2M (+22.5% Y/Y) beats by $50.53M.
    • Shares +6.3%.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:04 PM
  • WMB

    SEC declares Energy Transfer-Williams registration statement "effective"

    • Williams Cos. (WMB -3.9%) says the SEC has declared effective Energy Transfer Equity's (ETE -9.6%) S-4 registration statement, clearing WMB to mail its final proxy statement and schedule a shareholder vote for June 27 on its $33B merger with ETE.
    • ETE says the companies have agreed to a trial to be held June 20 and June 21 to determine whether the deal can close with a tax opinion from Latham & Watkins that the contribution of Williams’ assets to ETE should qualify as a 721 exchange.
    • Recent share price action indicates a higher likelihood that WMB will be able to hold ETE to the merger; the gap between WMB's trading price and the value of the cash-and-stock deal has narrowed by more than half over the past week, from nearly $8/share to less than $4/share.
    • Now read Yes, Williams Cos. really wants Energy Transfer deal to go through
     
     
     
     
    | 3:57 PM | 51 Comments
  • WETF

    Higher rates a boost to WisdomTree

    • The popularity of WIsdomTree's (WETF +4.2%) currency-hedged ETFs has kind of made this stock a play on a rising dollar. When the dollar gains vs. the yen and euro, investors move money into DXJ and HEDJ, but when the dollar retreats, so does interest in those funds.
    • This bout of hawkishness from the Fed - and the resultant strength in the greenback - has WisdomTree higher by more than 10% over the past handful of sessions.
    • Fun while it lasts, but Morgan Stanley's Michael Cyprys notes those two ETFs make up 51% of company AUM, leaving the company too vulnerable to dollar weakness for his blood.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:36 PM | 1 Comment
  • BCEI

    Bonanza Creek rebounds from huge loss despite downgrade

    • Bonanza Creek Energy (BCEI +27.2%) recovers roughly half of yesterday's huge loss, even after Imperial Capital downgraded shares to Underperform from In-line with a $1.50 price target, slashed from $3.50.
    • Imperial says BCEI's borrowing base reduction to $200M from $475M was far more severe than expected; it had assumed a 25% reduction based on comments from the company's Q1 earnings call that the upcoming reduction likely would be in line with industry.
    • "Avoiding a major borrowing base reduction was a critical component, alongside the divestiture of its RMI midstream asset, to develop a sufficient liquidity cushion to enable the company to return to drilling alongside its Niobrara peers," the firm says.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:30 PM | 14 Comments
  • FB

    Facebook is shuttering its FBX ad exchange; Criteo slumps in response

    • Facebook (FB +0.2%) is shutting down its FBX ad exchange, which launched in 2012 and (via ad tech partners) delivers Facebook ads based on browsing activity on non-Facebook sites. Criteo (CRTO -2.6%), which has delivered targeted e-commerce ads for its clients via FBX, has sold off on the news.
    • As it is, FBX has only functioned on Facebook's PC site - mobile accounted for 82% of Q1 ad revenue - and didn't support video ads. Other PC ad options, such as news feed ads recommending a user like/follow a page or shop at the advertiser's site (they can be purchased directly from Facebook), remain in place.
    • Facebook has been pruning its ad offerings in order to focus on high-quality formats that deliver a strong ROI. In March, the company ended a test for an automated ad-buying platform after seeing "many bad ads and fraud." More recently, it laid off ~40 workers within its LiveRail video ad unit (serves third-party publishers), and stopped doing business with LiveRail publishers that didn't meet Facebook's quality standards.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:29 PM | 6 Comments
  • CHK

    "Better opportunities ahead" for Chesapeake, but not now, analyst says

    • Chesapeake Energy's (CHK +7.5%) recent debt-for-equity swaps that helped reduce its near-term borrowings make sense but come at the expense of dilution to shareholders, Wunderlich analyst Jason Wangler says, arguing that better opportunities lie ahead to purchase CHK shares.
    • CHK's transactions over the past few months reflect a ~10% dilution in exchange for a ~4% reduction in the debt level, and Wangler expects CHK to continue making similar moves, specifically for its near-term maturities, to reduce debt and debt metrics; refinancing the debt would be more expensive, and potentially difficult, so reducing the overall debt is a positive, he says.
    • But the firm maintains its Hold rating and $6 price target on CHK as multiple and/or sizable deals likely are still to come, and "there could be better opportunities ahead once the dilution and debt reductions are completed."
     
     
     
     
    | 3:18 PM | 35 Comments

  • Technology - Top 5 Gainers / Losers as of 3:00 pm

    • Gainers: CSC +38%. NMBL +22%. PTI +11%. FH +10%. CNTF +9%.
    • Losers: MGT -18%. CCIH -9%. FNJN -9%. VNET -8%. SEMI -8%.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:00 PM

  • Energy leads markets to more gains

    • Oil's knocking on the door of $50 per barrel behind some bullish inventory numbers released last night and this morning, and it's got the energy sector (XLE +1.4%) leading the major averages nicely higher for a 2nd straight session.
    • The Dow (DIA +0.8%), S&P 500 (SPY +0.6%), and Nasdaq 100 (QQQ +0.6%)
    • Meanwhile in rates, the 10-year Treasury yield is flat at 1.87% and short-term rate markets are pricing in about a 60% chance of a Fed move in either June or July.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:00 PM | 3 Comments
  • BP

    BP starts Thunder Horse water injection project

    • BP (BP +3.3%) has started a water injection project at its Thunder Horse platform in the deepwater Gulf of Mexico to boost oil and gas recovery from one of the field’s three main reservoirs.
    • BP expects the improvements to allow the facility to recover an additional 65M boe over time.
    • The Thunder Horse platform, which began producing in 2008, has production capacity of 250K bbl/day of oil and 200M cf/day of gas.
    • BP is using Helix Energy Solutions' (HLX +8.4%) newbuild well intervention vessel Q5000 at Thunder Horse for workovers and well enhancement, including acid stimulation and water reduction.
    • Thunder Horse is operated by BP with a 75% working interest, while Exxon Mobil (XOM +0.5%) holds the remaining 25%.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:58 PM | 5 Comments

  • Energy - Top 5 Gainers / Losers as of 2:00 pm

    • Gainers: BCEI +29%. AREX +15%. LEI +16%. CWEI +14%. PES +13%.
    • Losers: TMST -13%. OTC:ANW -8%. ETE -7%.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:00 PM | 4 Comments

  • Financials - Top 5 Gainers / Losers as of 1:00 PM

    • Gainers: AAMC +9%. OCN +6%. TIPT +6%. YRD +6%. SAN +6%.
    • Losers: CBL -9%. AIII -6%.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:00 PM | 2 Comments
  • DY

    Dycom +14% to five-month highs following FQ3 beat, upside guidance

    • Dycom (DY +13.9%) surges after the specialty contracting company easily beat FQ3 earnings and revenue estimates and offered above consensus guidance.
    • DY issued upside guidance for FQ4, seeing EPS of $1.40-$1.60 vs. $1.36 analyst consensus estimate, and FQ4 revenues of $750M-$780M vs. $730.8M consensus.
    • DY said total revenue growth accelerated in FQ4, up 35%, including a 29% gain on an organic basis.
    • DA Davidson analysts say the growth appears to reflect increasing demand for fiber optic installation and other construction services from telecom network providers, with DY well positioned to capitalize on the demand as the largest provider of these services (Briefing.com).
    • Other providers of specialty contracting services are higher: PWR +3.4%, MTZ +3.4%, WPCS +5.5%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:59 PM
  • NOK

    Nokia rallies as CLSA upgrades "bombed-out" shares to Outperform

    • "If you are looking for revenue growth, stop reading. But if you're looking for a bombed-out stock with a reasonable valuation, solid management, strong balance sheet, a lot of bad news behind it, and significant optionality, read on," writes CLSA's Avi Silver, upgrading Nokia (NOK +4%) to Outperform from Underperform.
    • Silver, who has upped his target by $1 to $6.25, also thinks earnings estimates could rise as Nokia reaps synergies related to the Alcatel-Lucent merger, and is upbeat about the company's guidance for a 7%+ Networks division op. margin.
    • The upgrade comes two weeks after Nokia sold off in response to its Q1 report. and shortly after a Finnish union said the company could cut 10K-15K jobs globally.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:53 PM | 23 Comments

  • Midday Gainers / Losers

    • Gainers: INNL +46%. CSC +35%. BCEI +29%. OPXA +28%. NMBL +24%. NEOS +22%. SRPT +18%. RDEN +15%. DY +15%. LEI +14%.
    • Losers: AOI -14%. TMST -14%. MGT -13%. DV -14%. ESI-OLD -13%. AKER -12%. SPEX -11%. DL -11%. CBL -10%. EXPR -10%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:50 PM
  • ATLS

    Atlas Energy paid CEO Cohen $73.2M in cash as stock drops 95%

    • Atlas Energy (OTC:ATLS +2.5%) paid CEO Ed Cohen $73.2M in cash prior the 95% collapse in the company's shares and suspension from trading on the NYSE, Bloomberg reports.
    • Cohen's payments included $38.5M for cash-out of equity awards and a $32.5M severance, and his son, Chairman Jonathan Cohen, received a $30.6M cash-out and a $30.9M severance.
    • The CEO was among at least five executives who received cash payouts related to the ATLS merger with Targa Resources.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:48 PM | 24 Comments
  • ATGE

    DeVry Education -13% on day after CEO change

    • DeVry Education (DV -13.5%) is sharply lower in a delayed reaction to news that the company is replacing its CEO.
    • Today's decline flies in the face of a positive note from Piper Jaffray on the upside it sees from the CEO change.
    • Previously: DeVry Education selects new CEO (May 24)
     
     
     
     
    | 12:40 PM | 3 Comments
  • JACK

    Jack in the Box rallies with investor day meeting in full swing

    • Jack in the Box (NASDAQ:JACK) shoots up 6.6% after the outlook presented by management during an analyst and investor meeting looks encouraging.
    • Refranchising efforts are expected to add to profit growth over the next year.
    • Execs also said they expect to be competitive across dayparts in the U.S.
    • Today's gain comes with Jack's shares already up 19% since Q1 earnings were released.
    • Jack in the Box analyst day webcast
     
     
     
     
    | 12:10 PM | 1 Comment
  • NEOS

    Investors perk up on prospects of Neos Therapeutics' candy-flavored amphetamine; shares ahead almost 40% since Monday

    • Thinly traded micro cap Neos Therapeutics (NEOS +20.5%) is up on more than double normal volume. Shares have jumped almost 40% since Monday as investors appear to have awoken to the "market potential" of Adzenys XR-ODT (amphetamine), an extended-release orally disintegrating tablet formulation of the stimulant launched last week for the treatment of patients as young as six years of age with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). Some psychiatrists are alarmed that the product will be widely abused considering its candy flavor and ease of administration.
    • Previously: Neos Therapeutics launches Adzenys XR-ODT in the U.S. (May 16)
     
     
     
     
    | 12:06 PM | 3 Comments

  • Intuit -3.2% post-earnings; Credit Suisse stays Neutral

    • Intuit is lower today, down 3.2%, after an earnings report where the company beat and raised guidance but got a reiteration at Neutral by Credit Suisse on valuation.
    • The company did have a strong tax season (thanks to 10.6% growth in total TurboTax units), but "digging into it further," analyst Michael Nemeroff and team have concluded that QuickBooks Online sub growth was just in line with Street projections.
    • Online growth missed expectations as QBO net subscriber adds of 140K were "a touch light, resulting in ending subscribers of 1,397K (+45% yr/yr), ahead of guidance (~1,380K) but just in line with Street of 1,400K."
    • "While we're encouraged by the momentum / share gains in INTU's tax business, we believe mgmt's F2017 QBO subscriber guidance is starting to look a bit aggressive to us, especially since F3Q net additions were driven more by improved retention rather than stronger gross subscriber additions," Nemeroff writes.
    • Along with Intuit, Credit Suisse did raise its full-year estimates for EPS to $3.64 from $3.55, and on revenues to $4.67B from $4.616B. Intuit sees EPS and revenue coming at $3.63-$3.65 and $4.66-$4.68B respectively.
    • Michael Nemeroff ranks No. 890 out of 3,951 analysts evaluated at TipRanks.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:04 PM

  • Consumer Goods - Top 5 Gainers / Losers as of 12:00 pm

    • Gainers: RDEN +15%. MGPI +9%. NAV +9%. AXL +8%. STKL +7%.
    • Losers: AOI -13%. SPWH -9%. SEED -8%. CYRX -7%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:03 PM
  • CVX

    Chevron CEO Watson says climate change could boost company's business

    • Chevron (CVX +1.6%) CEO John Watson not only opposes shareholder proposals that want companies to explain the risk that climate change poses to business, he questions the entire premise, arguing that climate change might even prove positive for the company.
    • Ahead of today's shareholder meeting, Watson told WSJ that climate change might motivate a further shift from coal to natural gas, and that he "hope[s] to gain market share in some areas."
    • Watson's stance increasingly sets him apart from his oil counterparts, and some industry insiders fear that his opposition to the idea that climate change may challenge the oil industry could backfire.
    • Watson argues that his positions represent realism, saying that nearly every aspect of modern life depends on the use of fossil fuels, many Americans live paycheck to paycheck and do not want to spend more on energy, and developing nations care more about cheap energy and local pollution than climate change.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:57 AM | 46 Comments
  • LNG

    Cheniere set to export LNG from second Sabine Pass plant in August

    • Cheniere Energy (LNG +1.9%) plans to begin exporting liquefied natural gas from a second plant at its Sabine Pass terminal in Louisiana in August, based on the current progress being made at the facility.
    • "Actual project progress supports the achievement of substantial completion for Trains 1 and 2 by late May 2016 and September 2016, respectively. Trains 3 and 4 targeted substantial completion dates are April 2017 and August 2017, respectively," according to a new FERC filing.
    • Cheniere became the first exporter of U.S. shale gas in February with the start of shipments from the first unit at Sabine Pass.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:39 AM | 7 Comments
  • ACER

    Opexa up 28% on (early) expectations of positive Tcelna data in MS study

    • Thinly traded nano cap Opexa Therapeutics (OPXA +27.5%) is up on a whopping 120x surge in volume. Shares almost doubled since Monday before retracing as eager investors pile in apparently expecting positive results from the Phase 2b Abili-T trial assessing lead product candidate Tcelna (imilecleucel-T) for the treatment of secondary progressive multiple sclerosis, an FDA Fast Track designation. Last month, the company reported that 98% of all patient visits have been completed. The release of top-line data, however, is not expected until Q4.
    • Tcelna is a personalized T-cell immunotherapy that is specifically tailored to each patient's immune response profile to myelin, a white fatty substance that insulates nerve cells. Multiple sclerosis is characterized by damage to this insulation, called the myelin sheath.
    • Secondary progressive MS represents ~half of the total MS population. Patients have very limited treatment options.
    • Previously: Opexa bulls finally see favorable action; shares up almost 70% in two days (Nov. 24, 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 11:34 AM
  • DSW

    Price targets lowered on DSW

    • Investment firms reset expectations on DSW (DSW +7%) after factoring in the retailer's Q1 report and guidance update.
    • Jefferies lowers it price target on DSW to $26.
    • Telsey Advisory moves to a $23 PT from $26.
    • Canaccord Genuity turns the bearish of the bunch, dropping to a PT of $19.
    • Previously: DSW down after earnings miss in Q1 (May 24)
     
     
     
     
    | 11:21 AM | 1 Comment
  • T

    Bloomberg: AT&T involved in Yahoo bidding

    • In a surprise revelation, AT&T (NYSE:T) made a bid for Yahoo (YHOO -2.1%) and is still in the running for the core Internet business, Bloomberg reports.
    • They were out of the offing according to earlier reports. But they kept involved in the process through a stake in YP Holdings -- which was involved in the early round in April -- and while YP isn't pursuing the transaction any longer, AT&T is still around.
    • The interest from the telecom giant would present a formidable challenge for presumed frontrunner Verizon (NYSE:VZ). But Verizon didn't submit one of the highest first-round bids, a pair of the sources said.
    • The process has another week or likely more time to play out.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:12 AM | 65 Comments

  • Healthcare - Top 5 Gainers / Losers as of 11:00 am

    • Gainers: INNL +47%. OPXA +28%. NEOS +19%. CBYL +17%. CLRB +16%.
    • Losers: APHB -9%. AVXS -6%. GBSN -6%.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:00 AM

  • Oil pulls back sharply after testing $50

    • WTI crude oil shot up to as high as $49.50 per barrel following larger-than-expected inventory draws first reported by the API last night, and then confirmed by the EIA this morning.
    • It's dropped about $1 in the last few minutes though, as the EIA data also showed a build in gasoline inventories of 3.06M barrels (vs. an expected 1.5M barrel draw).
    • Texas tea is currently higher by 0.4% on the session at $48.80 per barrel. USO +0.1%, UGA -0.45%
    • ETFs: USO, OIL, UWTI, UCO, DWTI, SCO, BNO, DBO, DTO, UGA, USL, DNO, OLO, UHN, SZO, OLEM
     
     
     
     
    | 10:59 AM | 19 Comments
  • INST

    Instructure +6.1% as Oppenheimer reiterates Buy

    • Instructure (NYSE:INST) is up 6.1% today after Oppenheimer reiterated a Buy rating on the stock, noting three reasons for bullishness on prospects for its corporate learning product, vs. Cornerstone OnDemand (NASDAQ:CSOD).
    • The firm's Brian Schwartz points to midmarket as a "greenfield opportunity" with a lack of fitting solutions; corporate customers who already want complementary products, like performance management; and pipeline momentum.
    • Meanwhile this week, company CEO Joshua Coates filed effective Monday that he has acquired 10,000 shares of the company, at $16.9675. Shares are quoting currently at $18.22.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:57 AM
  • WDC

    Western Digital rallies on second upgrade in two days; Seagate also up

    • Barclays' Mark Moskowitz has upgraded Western Digital (WDC +5.8%) to Overweight, and upped his target by $3 to $60. He argues the valuation is too low, that hard drives still have a future, and that multiples can grow as Western brings 3D NAND products to market (via just-acquired SanDisk) and lowers its debt load.
    • The call comes a day after Cowen's Karl Ackerman upgraded to Outperform, while asserting the guidance Western is due to provide on Thursday "should help eliminate uncertainty" related to the SanDisk acquisition. He also cited low expectations, and declared SanDisk will help Western better serve enterprise and hyperscale (cloud data center) clients.
    • Seagate (STX +3.4%) is following Western higher. Both companies were hammered in late April in response to weak earnings and guidance. Western is up 13% on the week.

    Norway wants Statoil, Lundin to stay rivals

    • Norway’s government, seeking enhanced competition in the country’s oil industry, says it wants Statoil (STO +2.1%) and Lundin Petroleum (OTCPK:LNDNF) to remain rivals after the two companies deepened ties earlier this month.
    • Norway's state-controlled STO increased its interest in Sweden’s Lundin to 20.1% from 11.9% on May 3, after saying previously it had no plans to do so.
    • STO's move has prompted some analysts to suggest the company could be considering a complete takeover of Lundin, although STO CFO Hans Jakob Hegge has reiterated that the company has no plans to further increase its stake.
    • Norway's crude output has been chopped in half since 2000 and seeks to attract more companies to compete with STO, which operates more than 70% of the country’s petroleum output.

    • Ultra-thinly traded micro cap Innocoll (INNL +40.6%) is up on almost a 10x surge in volume, albeit on turnover of less than 50K shares, in response to its announcement of successful results in two Phase 3 clinical trials assessing lead product candidate XARACOLL (bupivacaine-collagen bioresorbable implant) for the treatment of postoperative pain relief.     • XARACOLL, a surgically implantable and bioabsorbable matrix of the anesthetic bupivacaine and collagen, is designed to provide sustained pain relief by delivering appropriate concentrations of bupivacaine at the surgical site for up to 72 hours.
